Posts.Content: Hi, it’s really good that you’ve found this site. Everyone is so helpful. I had a lumpectomy & breast reduction almost 3 weeks ago. It looks as though everyone’s experience is different. I stayed in hospital for 2 nights as had an issue post-op. I left hospital with 2 drains that were pesky & uncomfortable. I went back to the hospital to get them removed 2 days after discharge home. I managed the pain with paracetamol & ibuprofen and very occassional oral morphine. The dressings were removed 10 days after op. I’ve done physio as instructed and noticing it’s getting easier all the time. I’ve been out most days since op, not easy and sometimes I really have to dig deep!!   I’m usually a very fit & active 48 year old and am looking forward to gymming etc again but not going to rush it. From what I’ve read on here, some folks have gone back to work 3-4 weeks after surgery. I work for NHS and am very hands on!! My manager doesn’t want  me back until after radiotherapy.  Try to do some really lovely things this week before before your op. XxX
Posts.Title: Lumpoptomy and radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Thinking of you dminnimouse. Results day is hard BUT you’ll have answers and, if necessry, a plan. We all like a plan. On the sleep front, I’ve struggled for the last 6 weeks since biopsy then op. My bestie bought me a pillow spray & balm from m&s. I’ve used it for 2 nights & slept for 2 nights!!!!! Also downloaded the Calm app for deep & controlled breathing. Take care xXx
Posts.Title: Just hours away from getting my biopsy results so scared

Posts.Content: Hi, I’m 4 weeks post op to. I had a lumpectomy & bilateral reduction as cancer was quite large & I had a lot to spare!! I’m still needing regular paracetamol, not able to drive & very bruised & swollen.  My op wasn’t straightforward and I lost a lot of blood so I don’t know if this has affected me more than I realised.  I started to feel “normal” at the weekend and had a lovely time pottering about. However, I was in a lot of pain and om settee most of Monday!!!  I guess we’re all different but we’ll get there eventually. Take care xx
Posts.Title: Recovery four weeks after op

Posts.Content: Hi Aspen, How is it going post chemo #1?? Hope you’re feeling reasonably ok. You’re 2 days ahead of me hoping the chemo fog might have lifted a bit for you. I managed to find ice lollies in Iceland!! Who knew??  Has anyone experienced dizziness on Fec?? I realise it’s probably another side effect but wondered how long it might last?? The nausea subsided on day 5 to make way for sore throat and flu symptoms, now the tiredness has gone to be replaced with dizziness. I actuallty felt so fed up with it this afternoon I cried. It’s worse on sitting or standing and a bit easier if I lie down on my side. xXx
Posts.Title: * * * December Breast Cancer Chemo Club * * *

Posts.Content: Aspen, Totally agree!! Never a good time but this has to be the worst!! As the chemo nurse said to me today though “Get it done before Christmas and you’re one step nearer to kicking cancer’s ass” My kids are a bit older at 19 & 15 but I still feel for them.  We can do this!!!!
Posts.Title: * * * December Breast Cancer Chemo Club * * *

Posts.Content: Hi all, first chemo (Fec) on Friday. You know what I’m thinking?? Where the heck do I get ice poles/lollies from in December??? :-0
Posts.Title: * * * December Breast Cancer Chemo Club * * *

Posts.Content: So sorry Leolady, I thought today was chemo day!! I’d got the 19th in my mind!! Oh well, at least my good vibes etc were early rather than late eh?? Hope all goes well tomorrow xx
Posts.Title: Chemo farts

Posts.Content: APRILLEE - It could just be that your scalp is just sensitive. Did you cold cap? xx
Posts.Title: Hair follicles

Posts.Content: Hya Bustysusy, I’m very fortunate to have a friend who is a massage therapist and teacher  in a spa and has also had training in cancer & treatments. She showed me how to do lymphatic massage properly, it’s a very different tecnique to normal massage. I can’t remember why (chemo) but I’m sure she said deep massages should be avoided; this is what the article could have meant??
Posts.Title: Conflicting Information

Posts.Content: Hya LondonLass, I can’t do the either I’m afraid.
Posts.Title: WHOSE READY FOR A MEET UP??

Posts.Content: APRILLEE - it could be the beginning of your hair falling out but if you’ve used the cold cap, it might not be. I’ve read on here some people have a tender or itchy scalp and still keep a lot of hair. Xx
Posts.Title: Hair follicles

Posts.Content: Yep, JackG, going through radio therapy right now!! I’ve always hated rollercoasters and this one is no exception!! Let us off now please :-( xxx
Posts.Title: Cancer still in lymph nodes after chemo

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass - 23rd is good for me but understand if you go with 30th if that’s what the majority can do xx
Posts.Title: WHOSE READY FOR A MEET UP??

Posts.Content: Hi JackG - My situation is similar to yours. I had a 4.3cm tumour and sentinel nodes  removed Nov 17 followed by 6 sessions of FecT as cancer was in nodes. Had Axillary Node Clearence in May.....cancer in nodes so now having radio therapy to boob, armpit and collar bone. I was also gutted (and extremely angry) that the cancer was still lurking but trying to be positive in the knowledge that everything is being done to get rid of any more pesky cells.  Hang in there xx
Posts.Title: Cancer still in lymph nodes after chemo

Posts.Content: Hya, glad you’ve found this group. You are never alone with your thoughts and fears here - even at night.  Waiting is the worst bit of diagnosis. I’m quite new here but I’ve found so much support, humour and top tips on this site.  I Totally get that you’re scared, it’s horrible and you feel out of control. You will get through this. Everyone has different ways of coping. I try to deal with one day at a time, more than that is too much.  Try to plan things you enjoy doing with folk that you love and let them help you through this truly s**t time xx
Posts.Title: Awaiting breast biopsy results feel like I'm going mad

Posts.Content: OCRKate - I’ve been using Cetreben (very similar to Diprobase) since starting chemo as skin very dry. Used every morning after my shower whilst on Radiotherapy as recommended by radigraphers and only had very mild skin reaction. I’m fair and usually have very sensitive skin so pleased with how my skin was during treatment. Hope this helps xx
Posts.Title: Diprobase Cream and/or R1 & R2 cream

Posts.Content: Hya, your situation is very similar to mine. I had mammogram, scan & biopsy last week. Dr said lump on scan looked unusual then nurse went into "diagnosis" mode and went into detail about treatment, telling kids etc.  I posted in here for the first time over the weekend and everybody has been helpful, supportive & honest. Xxx
Posts.Title: Recent diagnosis before biopsy results

Posts.Content: Love these thank you @taralou!! Are we voting for a mantra?? My vote’s for the last one please xx
Posts.Title: Some positive quotes to help us along

Posts.Content: Fireman’s wife, your head’s got quite a covering already!! That’s Fab!! Mine is still baldie bald but have just started the T so hoping it starts sprouting for summer. JammyR, I’ve been lathering up a bit of Simple Shampoo in my hands and gently rubbing head every day in the shower. I then pat dry and moisturise with Simple. The wig chap recommended using an anti-dandruff shampoo as a one off to get rid of dry/scaley/flakey bits which I did when I felt brave enough!! JoDec - you look amazing!! Love your hair!! I know we don’t get a choice but I’d quite like platinum to!! It seems to be growing quick time.  xXx
Posts.Title: Hair Loss - Question about regrowth.

Posts.Content: Hi Scarlettemm, I had the injections to, I was ok injecting myself, wierd but ok.  I felt very cold, shivery & achey everywhere from the hips up. I had a very sore throat to. Paracetamol helped,  Hope this helps but we’re all different so you might be fine xx
Posts.Title: Filgrastim injections

Posts.Content: Hya,  I’m a year behind...diagnosed oct 2017 at Nottm City. However my name’s also (An)Nette so I thought I’d say Hi  ;-))))
Posts.Title: Diagnosed November 2016 treatments at Nottingham City Hospital anyone...

Posts.Content: Beedeb - Hya and welcome to the forum, I think it’s really lovely that you’re looking for support to help you support your mum. The tiredness is part of the chemo which is more significant in some people. Your mum will probably start to gradually pick up in a couple of days. Try to make sure she’s drinking plenty (2-3 litres a day), eating if she can and getting out for short walks daily if possible. I am not medically trained and if you’re worried, the best people to ask are your mum’s oncology/breast care team. Take care xxx
Posts.Title: Mum has started chemo...

Posts.Content: YABBADABBADOOOO!!! What brilliant news!! You must be over the moon!! So very pleased for you.  Celebrations??
Posts.Title: My results so pleased

Posts.Content: Hi all, just about to start my RT journey. Stsrt 23 sessions on 10th July after our short break. Bit apprehensive but I’m sure having travel companions on this thread will help. Xx
Posts.Title: July 2018 Radiotherapy Club

Posts.Content: lol!! Good to see you’re still hanging around Leolady56!! Xx
Posts.Title: July 2018 Radiotherapy Club

Posts.Content: Hi juniruni, welcome to the group. I think a lot of us were told pre-surgery that lymph nodes weren’t involved and there would probably be no need for chemo only to be told that we do need it as cells found. Head melt or what ?? It is impossible to stay positive all the time, especially around appointments and results. You’re worried, recovering from surgery and most probably shell shocked by it all. My children are 20 & 16 and can’t imagine what it must be like to have much younger children when you’re going through this.  As others will no doubt tell you, chemo is no picnic but it is completely doable. There is a monthly chemotherapy thread that’s full of top tips, hints and support. Have a look at the other threads to when you feel up to it. Hope this helps. xXx
Posts.Title: Her2- lymph node involvement

Posts.Content: Nightjar, you poor lady having to put up with a heavy drain for so long. I was shown how to empty mine daily, when they had drained less than 30mls in 24 hours they could be removed. I just rang the ward and went in. You must be so fed up!! Once it comes out, you will be more comfy and be able to have a proper wash/shower.  One more sleep then it will be gone!! xXx
Posts.Title: My Drain and I

Posts.Content: Hya,  You've had a massive shock to your system. Be really kind to yourself and take each day as it comes. Think about the next step and get your head rpind that before looking at the step after that.   I was diagnosed a week ago today and it feels like months!! Days (& nights) seem endless, BUT we'll get through it with the support of the people here. Hang in there xx
Posts.Title: Hi I've just been diagnosed with dcis I'm 31 and am awaiting an op...

Posts.Content: Hi Blaster, My hair started to fall out big time on day 15 post 1st cheno. The wig chap shaved my head and recommended baby shampoo, shower gel or soap then finish with a moisturiser. I use Simple shampoo as I found the smell of the baby shampoo was too strong and made me feel sick. Xx
Posts.Title: Head itching

Posts.Content: Mrsox, Lol!! Why do you think I walked so fast?? To resist the urge!!! Hehe!!! Hope all goes ok tomorrow. You’ll be fine once you’re in it & doing it. Trust me!! Xxxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Previous shell suit wearer and PROUD!!!!  Did walk a bit today but only about 20 minutes. Had an appointment and couldn’t face the tram in rush hour so drove instead. Being a shift worker, I’ve forgotten the frustration of drivng 4 miles in 1st gear!!! Joy of joys!!  Hope everyone else has managed to stretch thier legs today xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Deb, I had a 43mm tumour removed with good margins and a breast reduction at the same time 6 weeks ago.  I was a 32jj pre-op which was a pain to be honest. I’m glad I had the reduction as it means no reconstruction is necessary. The surgeon took 5 lymph nodes from the same incision as the limpectomy & reduction; I was expecting another incision for lymph nodes so I was relieved.  I wouldn’t say I love the my new boobs because of the circumstances but I’m reasonably happy with the shape. I think it’s a bit unfair the surgeon asking you to choose which incision which should be made - they’re the experts!!  xXx
Posts.Title: The roller coaster ride begins Surgery on Friday

Posts.Content: Mrsox, Sounds like Roland’s ready to chill out a bit bless him!! He sounds a right character.  Have you got your flowerdy docs yet??  Hope your scalp’s not too sore now you’re losing your hair.  Xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Whathappened, I love the Jewelley Quarter in Birmingham. We usually go to Premier Diamonds for a bit of bling. I’ve been promised a trip there when treatment, etc all over. Xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Cannon, hope your great nephew gets better very soon so he can go home. Feeling good today - a rarity after the T!! - so joined a friend for a walk and a natter. Felt great to be outdoors spotting the signs of spring. Hope those of us not able to get out and about due to illness or s/e will feel better soon xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Well done Toxophilite!! You still gottit!! Not only have you relearned how to shoot, you’ve taken on a different method of shooting and smashed it - literally!! You rock!! Pleased to report I walked to happiness this morning with a friend who’s recently had a p/e and dvt. Was lovely to be out chatting and walking in the sunshine. We also managed coffee & cake afterwards.....rude not to we thought!! Hope others have managed to get out to.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Had a lovely 1 1/2 walk in the sunshine with my sister. We walked in the park and reminsed as we passed our old school. It was goid to be out in the fresh air for a bit. Took my eldest to 2 appointments today so shattered tonight. Sorry for lack of photographic evidence from walk - stupid i-phone!! Xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Aww, Jacmatholmad, I’ve been far too busy licking my own wounds to realise  that ohers are facing other battles. I’ll keep everything crossed for tomorrow. Hope RT is stronger than seroma and boots it out!! I’m going for wife/mum of the year with pizza lunch!! Leolady - thanks for the hug xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Jacmatholmad, Bigguy not managed to do outdoors today :-( Still feeling too whoozy. Last GCSF injection today so hoping to be able to increase my humanning very soon.  Have I seen you’re doing RT?? Xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Mrsox, Your poor lad’s still struggling a bit, bless him. My OH gets a touch of S.A.D. He’ll be better when the clocks go forward and he can get himself in the garden again!! Enjoy your trip to Manchester both of you. Good to see you back by the way xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: My trip out today was for Oncology clinic :-( only walk was to clinic & back from car but did manage to run up & down 4 flights of stairs without resus!! I was impressed I’ve still got it!!  Dr didn’t buy my suggestion of 4 weeks for chemo or omitting/having alternative to GCSF injections. However she did listen to my endless questions and wasn’t nicey when I cried so I could reign it back in!!  So bloods on Saturday and maybe chemo. Done a bit too much at home since hospital so feet up with a hot choc now. Take care everybody xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Glad to see you’re feeling brighter today Aspen. Sometimes we need to give in just a little bit and then get back on it!! Xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Go on Leolady....dare you to gallop in JL!! Photo of gallopping feet as evidence please!! Enjoy your lunch. I love a friends’ lunch but sometimes a Me Party is better...phone, people watching, coffee doesn’t go cold coz talking...... Spoil yourself xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Mrsox, Chemo is being a nuisance - not even got any energy to go for a sniff round the estate :-( You & Roland can do a bit for me.  I have tried to do a bit of exercise but really can’t as feel so bleurgh after. Next week will different...walking every day....no excuses!!  Glad you’re feeling well enough to get out wi the lad & roland.  xXx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Jac, number 3 of 18 means you’re 1/6 way through rads!!! That’s an achievement!! Glad your daughter’s appointment went well, it’s hard supporting them through stuff when you feel c**p. Yep...injections are awful. For me, the side effects are as bad if not worse than the chemo itself. I started taking one of the anti-sick again yesterday and it does help a bit. I told the consultant about the awfulness of side effects from GCSF last cycle but she didn’t change them. Maybe I’ll be more determined this time when I tell her how bad it’s been!! Hope you’re resting up ready for another zzzzap tomorrow. xXx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Mrsox.....I’d struggle to decide....is having both pairs an option??? Lol!!! Hope you’re not feeling too chemoed xxxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Thinking of you today Leolady!!! Lets hope you’re able to gallop out of your appointment xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Mrsox, changing your name is funny!! It’s adding to the intrigue knowing you’ve got an exotic name in “real” life!! We walked 3 miles by the river this aft, took mother in law who was shocked at my pace!! I was on a mission!! Was good to be out. Battery fully charged now ready for chemo #3 xXx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Leolady....We managed (drum roll please....) 15 minutes gentle walk!! Just long enough for frozen pizza to cook!! Mind you, it was further than I thought I’d go! Your walk looks lovely, love an upper to get the heart going. Won’t be listening to Mr Ball - emotional wreck today :-( xXx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Whathappened....that’s so very funny!! I can’t believe it!! We went a few years ago for a new engagement ring for my 40th bday then I was hooked!! Since then I’ve had replacement wedding ring and ring to celebrate our Silver Wedding last year. BC is the perfect reason to go back for more!! Hubster has promised, LOL!! What a brilliant craft to do, hope you’re well supplied!! Xxx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Resa47, Glad you’ve got a plan. We like plans as then we have an idea of what’s happening when. We’re all here with you. There’s no need to do any of this alone.  xXx
Posts.Title: Saw my consultant today for my treatment plan

Posts.Content: Leonaw123, Sorry you’ve found yourself in this awful situation but glad you’ve found this site. I think waiting times varies a lot between trusts. I was fortunate and waited only 5 days for initial result & a further 5 days for full results & treatment plan. I think this is the “gold standard”. From reading other people’s experiences of waiting times, 2-3 weeks doesn’t seem unusual.  I know it’s hard, but do try not to second guess or read into what was said at your last appointmemt. Have you got a Breast Care Nurse you can speak to while you wait? It seems unlikely that there’s only one doctor in the clinic that can see you. Keep us informed & take care xx
Posts.Title: Advice needed please!!

Posts.Content: PMPL!!!! Welcome back MrSox!!!! Sounds like you had a charming neighbour in hospital!! Glad to see you’re back and posting - we’ve missed you!! Are you a nurse??  Hope recovery’s going well and you’re not in too much pain. xXx
Posts.Title: mrsox

Posts.Content: Simba4me, You’re doing really well, let the feelings happen and rant when you need to.  We can only cope with so much Fran. This is probably your “last straw” that has tipped you over the edge.  I am also a coper and prefer to soldier on and deal with stuff but sometimes we have to give in for a bit, give ourselves a break & let everyone else carry us a bit xx
Posts.Title: Having a bit of a melt down

Posts.Content: Dayityrose - So sorry you’re going through this bleeping poop. We have enough to deal with!!!! Is it worth appealing against your refusal?? Also, did you have professional help filling the form in?? Our hospital has a MacMillan advice centre and the lady was a massive help. You can also go to Citizen’s advice for support to complete the form. I managed to get it on first application with no interview or anything, just questions over the phone. Good luck with it all xx
Posts.Title: Does anyone know anything about PIP?

Posts.Content: Hi Jet999, I used the cold cap but, unfortunately, I still lost my hair. I’ve got a fab wig that I wear out of the  house as I feel ”exposed” to show my baldie head outdoors. I’m sure there will be more folks who have been successful that chip in. xXx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and cold caps

Posts.Content: Hi Zanib, I had a large bruise on my breast where the biopsy was taken. I also ached in my armpit, a bit like when you’ve got a cold or virus.  If you’re worried, it might be a good idea to contact your nurse or clinic. xXx
Posts.Title: Pains in both shoulders and mastectomy

Posts.Content: Simba4me, You will get there, your daughter’s right. This is not a race, it’s a journey that we will all complete in a different way taking a different route but getting to the same place in the end. The pain is still getting me down to as is lack of sleep BUT we’re in it together and here for each other. I’ve worked out if I just potter about in the house and rest much more I’m virtually pain free but fed up & down. If I do a bit more & go out & about I’m sore but more positive.  It’s more frustrating because we’re all different we all heal (physically and emotionally) and there is no set recovery time; unlike what drs tell us eh????? So, Fran, chin up and get yourself well in your time in your way.  Love xXx
Posts.Title: Having a bit of a melt down

Posts.Content: Happy Birthday JMP/Judith!!! Hope it’s been appointment free and lovely xx
Posts.Title: Uplifting things

Posts.Content: Thanks for this mrsox ;-) We all need a reminder sometimes xx
Posts.Title: Uplifting things

Posts.Content: Hi Phaedra, I have experience of these medicines as my son has taken them for 10 years for osteogenesis imperfecta (Brittle Bone Disease).  I am not medically qualified, just a mummy who was also worried about these drugs. The medicine reduced our son’s fracture rate from a broken leg/arm every 12 weeks to every 12 months. It also helps his bone pain a lot. So, our family, the drugs have been amazing. However, there are other parents that I know well are against them.  We have experience of i/v and oral bisphosphanates. He’s been taking oral medicine on and off for 5 years. Sunday is “tablet day”; take tablet and drink 1 pint of water whilst on xbox/ipad then carry on day. He has had no problems or side effects apart from a broken neck of femur 4 years ago which was probably linked to the medicaton.  So, bit of a long one but it might help.
Posts.Title: Anyone refused to take bisphosphonates?

Posts.Content: Googieswife, Hello from me to!! Welcome to the group :-))))) It’s ok to be nervous about surgery, it’s not something we do every day is it?? The surgeons, anaesthetists, nurses, porters etc do do it every day and will look after you. Make sure you tell them how you’re feeling so they can reassure you.  There is a thread/group for almost everything, have a look around. There’s one called “the operation” that you might find useful as there’s folk on there that have had or will be having surgery soon like you. There’s even one called “awake” where you can go in the small hours and chat : Hope all goes well tomorrow. Let us know how you’re doing xx
Posts.Title: New and scared!

Posts.Content: Thanks Toxophilite!! I’m not good with tec unless is blaringly obvious!! Thing is, at work, I’m the “go to” for computer, printer etc but haven’t a clue why!!
Posts.Title: Friend Request

Posts.Content: Hi Concepta, A cycle is 21 days, day one being chemo day, 3 weeks will start for you on 27th Feb; your 2nd treatment should then be 20th March.  HOWEVER....try not to even “pencil” in all your cycles until treatment complete. It will help to know roughly when it will finish but I wouldn’t set it in stone.  It is completely understandable that you want to take control, organise stuff etc but as many folk (me included) know, cancer and chemo have thier own plan and schedules go out of the window!! Hope this helps xx
Posts.Title: Working out when my Chemo will be

Posts.Content: Good evening clever teckie types Can somebody tell me how I send a friend request??  I’ve looked in my area bit, I can see requests but not how to actually request. Thanks xx
Posts.Title: Friend Request

Posts.Content: Hya Sazzat, Welcome to our group. We are a friendly bunch who wobble, rant, cry and laugh together.  Let me say first that what you are doing to help your sister and family is brilliant. It sounds like you’re already being an amazing support to her. I see from your post that you’ve been doing some research, please stick to this site, Cancer Research or NHS as a lot of websites are out of date and can be misleading. My initial diagnosis was “curable” then “treatable” to and it completely knocked me sideways. You go from, this can be cured and kind of forgotten to bleep, I’ve got to live with this and it might come back into life again without an invite!! However, by being on this site, I’ve realised that folk can get on with life after diagnosis, surgery, chemo, etc, it’s just a case of getting used to a new normal. That is a long way down the line for you & your family. Right now, all you have to do is get through each day with and for your sister surronding her with love and support. Keep in touch with us all. xXx
Posts.Title: New here and supporting my sister with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks for the update.  Fill your week doing things you love to keep you busy. The waiting is the worst and most frustrating thing. xXx
Posts.Title: What did your lump feel like?

Posts.Content: Love the song Lindsay, the room must be dusty though as my eyes & nose are running ;-) Well done on completing RT xx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Just saying “Hello”. Had my Radio Therapy planning appointment today, due to start on 10th July. Bit apprehensive about it but I’m sure it will OK xx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Thanks for this.  I’m due to start chemotherapy soon. My hair isn’t long (earlobe length bob) but it is very thick. I am in a dilemma of what to do before I start.  Were your team able to tell you the chance of your hair falling out before your treatment? Did you try the Cold Cap??  Xx
Posts.Title: Loosing your hair...

Posts.Content: Hi bethanerin1,  It looks like recovery varies so much. It could be you’ve overdone things a bit and your body’s reminding you that you need to heal.  I had my surgery 4 weeks ago and was feeling much better but overdid the weekend a bit and ended up in the settee all day Monday.  Keep an eye on things and ring your nurse if you’re worried. xXx
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy and Sentinol Node Biopsy 3 weeks ago.

Posts.Content: Bevp69 - Hya, glad you’ve found us. If you’ve been referred on the urgent pathway, you’re normally seen within 2 weeks. Hope this helps xx
Posts.Title: How long is it usual to wait for urgent mammograme pls xxx

Posts.Content: Simba4me, you're so not alone. You & your husband have each other and you have all the lovely peoples in here to keep you company As someone else has suggested, how about a bit of early Christmas shopping to cheer you both up??  Chin up chicken xx
Posts.Title: Feeling alone

Posts.Content: Hya Shirl3, I don’t think this is a silly question at all, in fact no question is a silly question. I had vest type tops that go over head & jama bottoms but I’ve heard of other folk on here saying that they had button up and they were better. You might want to look on “The Operation” thread in the breast cancer bit as there’s loads of top tips for surgery on there and some of us have had surgery fairly recently. Xx
Posts.Title: What to wear after a lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Dreamthief - Looks good but I think I’ll stick to a Mojito!! Lol!! xXx
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Thank you, this has reassured me a little as I have to start taking Tamoxifen soon. I was having a bit of a freak out until I read your post.  Xx
Posts.Title: tamoxifen problems

Posts.Content: Hya 8uttercup and welcome to the exclusive club where the drinks are free, fun & sunshine for everyone....all that’s missing is the sea!! I’m the same age as you, bonus points for naming that tune!!  I’ve actually finished my chemo 4 weeks ago and just had 2nd op but sticking around for a bit!! Lol!! So, you’re almost through the chemo already, well done. The next bit of the chemo is very different from the ”feck” one but different for everyone to and still doable.  Where are you based?? I’m in the Midlands and fortunate to have a Maggie’s centre nearby which is an excellent source of info & support but, more importantly, compassionate experienced volunteers & staff who make fantastic tea & coffee and listen.  Do stick around, we’re a good crowd xxx
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hya lelotron, You could just be post-op rough or codiene upsetting you, BUT If you haven’t already done so, call your breast  nurse or gp. Let the experts decide and treat you with whatever they need to make you well again xx
Posts.Title: Ductectomy - what should I expect?

Posts.Content: Lou1234 - Welcome to the club!! I can’t really add to what Ruby Rose has said as it’s such good advice. Hope you manage to get some assistance soon xx
Posts.Title: Hello, I’m new to this and would love a friendly hello

Posts.Content: Wow Jinky47, what a hand you’ve been dealt!! So much to deal with but it sounds like you’re gettng through it with your head held high and your dignity intact.  Hope you manage to get some vital rest in the midst of everything that’s going on. xXx
Posts.Title: New here

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm quite new this to. My diagnosis was 2 weeks ago today and I have surgery tomorrow. It's a scary, horrid & extremely anxious time BUT we've found it and it's going to be evicted!! My top tip for you which has helped me is talk, talk, talk!! Telling folk is hard but  I was so surprised how many of us go through it. It seems everybody knows somebody who's had breast cancer and are living a full life afterwards. This grouo is amazing for listening & advice to. Take care of yourself xxxx
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thank you for this xx
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: taralou - You poor lady :-( I really struggled with my first T - pain, dizziness, oral thrush..... my 2nd & 3rd doses were reduced to 60%.  Although it still wasn’t pleasant, it was much more doable. I can’t help with the skin but it looks like other folk have been able to give you some good advice. I’ve changed my face moisturiser to a Boots no.7 for very dry skin for my chemo cheeks and put a nail strengthener on as they’re splitting just above nail bed :-( I agree with Leolady and urge you to get in touch with your unit as they can give us meds to help us cope with the side effects xxx
Posts.Title: Skin falling off my fingers?? Chemo face!!!

Posts.Content: Re: bisphosphanates Hi, I have very limited experience with Pamidronate and Risedronate. I am not an expert with a medical opinion or qualification, just a mum. My son had iv Pam for 7 years and has had oral Risedronate for almost 5 years with no ill effects. He has the medicine for the treatment of Brittle Bone Disease. I have got 2 friends, however, who strongly regret letting thier child have the drugs as thier bones have gone over dense and, therefore, more brittle. We have always been told by dentists that jaw necrosis from bisphosphanates is extremely rare but if my son needs any dental work it would have to be done in Sheffield at the dental hospital. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: NICE draft guidelines on treatment of primary breast cancer

Posts.Content: With you on the “breast cancer is a good one to have, it’s so treatable” that and “it’s only hair, it will grow back”  GRRRRRRRRRRRRR Angry with cancer of Notts.
Posts.Title: Sweats awful

Posts.Content: MrSox, I feel like hitting em all, all a the time!!!  Yours, sat in an old person/priority seat on tram coz i don’t want germs. And no, I don’t even care. Angry of notts
Posts.Title: Sweats awful

Posts.Content: Herradiman, First of all welcome to the groups, they’re full of fantastically strong people who will help you through every step of this poo-storm in your life. Secondly, breathe and make a bit of time for you and your little one while you wait for scans, results, etc. Sending hugs to you xx
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed grade 3 two lymph nodes 29years old please help m...

Posts.Content: You’re very welcome taralou. I went to a “Look Good, Feel Better” afternoon which was really good but in larger Boot’s shops there’s a MacMillan trained adviser on the No.7 counter, the one I saw was really helpful and gave me loads of tips and showed me how to use products I’ve never seen let alone used!! Because they’re MacM trained they know all about how chemo, etc affects our skin. Good luck with the return to work, hope it goes well xx
Posts.Title: Eyebrows and eyelashes - What do you do when they are gone??

Posts.Content: Aspen - Soooooo......did you get chemo #6???? Been thinking about you today xxxxxx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Sammystaff - Really sorry but this has made me chuckle a bit too much!!! Totes inapropes of I know sorry!! Exactly the same thing happened to me at the same stage as you and I was looking intently into the loo for “wildlife” after each trip but never saw anything, it stopped on it’s own. Mine was sore like with piles to. I‘m quite hairy for a girl so I attributed it to hair loss down there. If your daughter has worms though, it could be that as it’s extremely contagious and will need treating. xXx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: taralou - My eyebrows have almost gone so I pencil them in. My eyelashes went a while ago and I’ve found my eyes are too sensitive to wear any make up at all. I wanted to look & feel like you do so I “go all out” with the rest of my face instead - concealer, foundation, powder & highlighter. I decided if I do rest of my face, folk might not notice my eyes!! When do you finish RT and go back to work?? Xx
Posts.Title: Eyebrows and eyelashes - What do you do when they are gone??

Posts.Content: Sammystaff - Hi, sorry to hear about your hair. I had mine cut very short but had it shaved a couple of days later as was falling out in clumps. The chap in the wig shop did mine for me then I walked out wearing my wig!! Hope this helps xx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: LiziX - I bought a supernarket “own brand” for £5 one as recommended by chemo unit...was useless!! Took it back and bought Braun one for £15, this one has been fine. You might want to get a baby toothbrush too and toddler toothpaste as adult toothpaste can be a bit harsh on sore or delicate mouth. Hope this helps. Aspen - How are you getting on this time?? Better than last time I hope xx In other news...I walked to post box wearing nothing but SPF 30 on my baldy head!! Felt liberated!!
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Geneva- So sorry to see the T got you!! I think a lot of us have been hit like you :-( Is your temperature ok?? Sometime’s it’s possible to feel cold with a fever or low temp. Xx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: JammyR, Sorry can’t tag - phone decided not to play!! I had the same thought as you re: April Chemo Thread...The end’s getting closer!! As you know, the T wasn’t kind to me for the first cycle but the second one has been much more doable as dose was reduced to 60%. My T s/e start on day 4 but everyone’s different aren’t they?? I think the first 2-3 days are usually ok because of the steroids giving you an artificial high. xXx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Aspen - YAAAAAYYYYYYY!!!!!!! That’s amazing news!!!! So pleased for you that you’re done :-))). I know you’ve struggled with the T, hope the s/e leave you alone this time and let you get back to life. Thinking of you xxx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Leolady56 - Well, today is the day when you get to kick out those pesky cancer cells for good!! Hope your PICC settled with some paracetamol and isn’t sore anymore. You will do the chemo, you really will. It’s not easy but it’s doable.  Baldy head will be out again outside today. My youngest assures me it won’t be starring in his presence outdoors - bless him!!  I’ll be thinking of you today and helping you hold your big girl pants up. Go blast it!! xXx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: taralou - Thank you!! It was just too warm to cover up!! Sat in a cafe garden with it out today!! We’re all different though and it’s not right for everyone. I definately don’t feel ready to go to the shops or anywhere just yet!! My son has said he won’t go out with me baldy!! He took the longest to see it when I first lost my hair though so not surprised!! Bless him xx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***
